title: Enhancing Portuguese Variety Identification with Cross-Domain Approaches
author: Hugo Sousa (Faculty of Sciences, University of Porto), Ruben Almeida (Faculty of Engineering, University of Porto), Purificacao Silvano (Faculty of Arts and Humanities, University of Porto), Ines Cantante (Centre of Linguistics, University of Porto), Ricardo Campos (Department of Informatics, University of Beira Interior), Alipio Jorge (Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence)
relevance_why: The development of cross-domain language variety identification models may offer insights into audio-language modeling and improve multilingual processing in Haohe Liu's work.
background: Discriminating between varieties of a language, using natural language processing to identify features of Portuguese varieties effectively.
contribution: This paper introduces a cross-domain language variety identifier for Brazilian and European Portuguese to solve issues of linguistic bias in language models, achieving better generalization across domains.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods in language variety identification often struggled with cross-domain capabilities and were biased towards known linguistic features.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon existing models by employing a novel delexicalization approach and a robust training protocol that enhances the model's transfer capabilities.

key_innovation: Utilizes delexicalization to mask named entities and thematic content, which helps the model generalize better across different domains and varieties of Portuguese.
real_world_impact: This research could lead to more inclusive language processing tools, aiding automated systems in legal and medical fields that require precise language variety discrimination.
limitations: The dataset is highly unbalanced across domains, potentially affecting model performance in less represented segments.

new_terms.delexicalization: **Delexicalization** refers to the process of removing or replacing specific lexical items from a text during training to reduce model reliance on vocabulary and improve feature generalization.

open_sourcing: The code, corpus, and model have been open-sourced to foster further research in language variety identification.
